questions.question: Which statement best describes a Design Pattern?
questions.option_a: A reusable block of code that can be copied directly into any project.
questions.option_b: A proven solution to a common problem in a specific context.
questions.option_c: A strict implementation that must be followed exactly.
questions.option_d: A model used only for performance optimization.
questions.explanation: Design patterns provide proven solutions to recurring software design problems.

questions.question: Why are design patterns useful to study and apply?
questions.option_b: They prevent reinventing the wheel by offering tested solutions.
questions.option_d: They remove the need for documentation.
questions.explanation: Design patterns give reusable solutions that save time and reduce rework.

questions.question: What does the 'Consequences' section of a design pattern describe?
questions.option_b: Benefits, trade-offs, and impacts of using the pattern.
questions.option_c: All existing systems that use the pattern.
questions.explanation: The Consequences section explains the advantages and disadvantages of applying the pattern.

questions.question: Behavioral design patterns focus primarily on:
questions.option_b: Communication and responsibility assignment among objects.
questions.explanation: Behavioral patterns define how objects communicate and coordinate responsibility.

questions.question: Which requirement is essential for implementing the Singleton pattern?
questions.option_a: The constructor must be publicly accessible.
questions.option_b: The class must ensure only one instance exists.
questions.option_c: Clients must create new instances freely.
questions.option_d: Instances must be cloned at runtime.
questions.explanation: Singleton restricts the instantiation to a single instance for the program.

questions.question: Which is a disadvantage of the Singleton pattern?
questions.option_b: It can lead to tight coupling and difficulties in unit testing.
questions.option_c: It forces observers to register manually.
questions.explanation: Singleton introduces global state, leading to tight coupling and testing challenges.

questions.question: Which responsibility belongs to the Subject in the Observer pattern?
questions.option_a: To implement the reaction behavior when notified.
questions.option_b: To maintain and notify a list of observers when its state changes.
questions.option_c: To determine which observer should react first.
questions.option_d: To fetch data on behalf of the observers.
questions.explanation: The Subject manages observer registration and notifies them of state changes.

questions.question: Which of the following patterns is classified as Creational?
questions.option_b: Singleton
questions.explanation: Singleton is a Creational pattern because it controls object creation.

questions.question: What type of relationship does the Observer pattern establish?
questions.option_b: One-to-many dependency
questions.explanation: Observer defines a one-to-many dependency between subject and observers.

questions.question: Which is an advantage of the Observer pattern?
questions.option_b: It allows multiple objects to be updated automatically without modifying their classes.
questions.option_c: It tightly couples observers to the subject.
questions.option_d: It removes the need for state management in the subject.
questions.explanation: Observer promotes loose coupling and automatic update propagation.

questions.question: Where did the concept of design patterns originate before being adopted into software engineering?
questions.option_a: The Gang of Four invented it from scratch.
questions.option_b: It came from architectural design theory.
questions.option_c: It originated in database normalization techniques.
questions.option_d: It was created by UNIX developers.
questions.explanation: Design patterns were inspired by architect Christopher Alexanderâ€™s work.

questions.question: What is the main role of the 'Name' component in a design pattern?
questions.option_b: To provide a shared term that aids developer communication.
questions.explanation: The Name allows developers to reference the pattern easily during discussions.

questions.question: Structural patterns primarily focus on:
questions.option_b: Object communication rules.
questions.option_c: Class and object composition into larger structures.
questions.explanation: Structural patterns describe how objects combine to form larger structures.

questions.question: What is a key characteristic of a Singleton class's instance retrieval method?
questions.option_a: It creates new instances every time.
questions.option_b: It must be private.
questions.option_c: It returns the same instance each time.
questions.option_d: It requires passing an existing instance.
questions.explanation: Singleton ensures every call retrieves the same global instance.

questions.question: What is the core problem the Singleton pattern solves?
questions.option_b: Ensuring only one instance of a class exists.
questions.option_d: Converting an interface to another interface.
questions.explanation: Singleton ensures controlled, one-instance-only access.

questions.question: How do observers receive updates from the subject?
questions.option_b: Through a callback method defined in the observer interface.
questions.option_c: By reading private internal state directly.
questions.option_d: By sharing the same memory pointer.
questions.explanation: Observers implement an update() callback method invoked by the subject.

questions.question: Why is the Gang of Four book significant?
questions.option_b: It formalized widely-known software design patterns.
questions.option_d: It created programming languages for design.
questions.explanation: The GoF cataloged and standardized design pattern terminology and structure.

questions.question: Which part of a pattern describes how its components interact?
questions.option_b: Problem
questions.explanation: The Solution explains the structure and relationships between pattern components.

questions.question: Which pattern best applies to managing a shared printer spooler?
questions.option_b: Strategy Pattern
questions.explanation: Singleton provides a single shared access point to manage shared resources.

questions.question: A subscriber receiving automatic newsletter updates without the publisher knowing its details demonstrates:
questions.option_b: Loose coupling from the Observer pattern.
questions.explanation: Observer decouples subjects from the concrete details of observers.

questions.question: Which is a documented drawback of the Observer pattern?
questions.option_b: It can make notification ordering unpredictable.
questions.option_d: It forces all observers to react identically.
questions.explanation: Observer does not define or guarantee notification order.

questions.question: The 'Problem' section of a design pattern describes:
questions.option_b: When and why the pattern should be applied.
questions.explanation: The Problem explains the context and motivation for applying the pattern.

questions.question: Which pattern category focuses on object creation?
questions.option_b: Structural
questions.explanation: Creational patterns deal with how objects are instantiated.

questions.question: The idea that a pattern can be reused indefinitely without repeating the same implementation highlights that patterns are:
questions.option_b: Rigid specifications.
questions.explanation: Patterns are flexible templates that guide design decisions.

questions.question: What does notifyObservers() do in the Observer pattern?
questions.option_b: Registers a new observer.
questions.option_c: Calls update() on each registered observer.
questions.explanation: notifyObservers() loops through observers and invokes their update method.
